utterances: Well, we learned that lesson.
Anyway, Drew Baden, I'm sorry, that's all the time we have.
I thank you very much for that primer on LHC.
My pleasure, thank you.
Drew Baden is professor and chairman of the physics department at the University of Maryland in College Park.
We're going to take a short break, and when we come back, we're heading off to Mars.
So don't go away.
In the aftermath of the hurricane, thousands of people face another day in crisis.
Again, we hear from NPR's Farai Chideya, who shares the stories of three individuals dealing with the storm in different ways and in different places.
Brenda Morris is a single parent of four children and the caretaker for her ill brother and mother.
She's in New Orleans.
How many people are in your home right now?
I've got my mama, my brother, my sister.
And my mother's on dialysis, my brother has cancer, and they got me and my niece.
Has anyone offered to help you out in getting medical care for your brother and your mother?
No one.
I went to the hospital and they turned me back 'cause they said they're not taking no one.
I asked, I said, `What should I do?
They said, `We don't know.'
What are you going to do if you can't get any care for your brother or your mother in the next couple of days?
I don't know.
I have enough water and we got chips and stuff, you know, to snack on, but as far as the food, we got about two days of canned goods and a lot of water--lots of water and lots of juice.
Tell me a little bit about your neighborhood.
How are people in your neighborhood doing?
Are you able to get in touch with other people who live right around you?
All the people in the neighborhood just chipping together to feed each other and trying to stay alive, giving each other water and stuff like that.
Well, we certainly hope that everything gets better for you soon, and appreciate you taking the time to speak with us.
Thank you.
And now to Houston, where we speak with Rodney Whitney Jr. He's the founder and CEO of a New Orleans-based marketing company.
Whitney evacuated the city on Saturday.
Thank you so much for joining us.
Mr. RODNEY WHITNEY Jr. (New Orleans Evacuee): Thank you.
Have you been able to get in touch with any of your friends or family members who are still in New Orleans?
No, we have not been able to reach anyone back--we're unsure the status of friends that stayed back.
Just watching the devastation on the news just literally just brought me to tears.
The city that I know and love and grew up in just will never be the same.
I understand you have a cousin who's a state trooper.
Have you been able to talk to him about what he's seen?
Yes, I did.
I spoke to him, and he told me that what we're seeing on the news is nothing to what really is going on.
It's really, like, five times, 10 times worse than what is actually being reported.
They're literally pulling bodies out of the water by the dozen.
I don't know if that meant that they weren't allowed--reporters were not being allowed in certain areas or what--I don't know what that meant.
Thank you.
I had a brief conversation with my father, but it was very, very short just because of the difficulties communicating.
But at least I was able to hear from him and to let me know that he was safe and that he was doing well.
What did he say about where he was, what the conditions were?
He was based down in the Ninth Ward, which received just a ton of water, but he was evacuated to the French Quarter.
He's currently staying in one of the hotels.
And he just talked about the city being in ruins.
What do you expect your role will be in trying to support your family at this moment?
Well, I think it'll be, you know, hopefully, a couple of different ways--I mean, any way that we can help financially to assist them.
I'll look to, you know, try to give some assistance to them, and my brothers will, as well.
We'll just try to do whatever we can.
I mean, it's a tough situation and, you know, all you can do is, you know, band together, join together as family, and try to figure out a way that you can be productive.
And what would you like to see the country do as a whole around this situation?

Well, hopefully, just acknowledge--get behind the notion that this is a devastating situation that has happened, and if you look at areas like the Ninth Ward--again, being a person of color, quite a few of those people that live in that area maybe don't have the means, and maybe that's why they weren't able to get out and evacuate.

And those are the people that are really going to need the nation's assistance, both on a nationwide but also on a personal level, to really try to go back into that community and just try to give any assistance that they possibly can to help these people repair their lives, because it's not going to be an easy situation to bring these people back up to respectability just because of the devastation that has happened.
David Cole, thank you so much.
Thank you so much.
Farai Chideya, NPR News.
There're a lot of people anxiously listening for what Pope Francis is going to have to say today.
The pope is in Myanmar.
He's meeting with that country's civilian, military and religious leaders, and the question is what he will say about violence against the country's Rohingya Muslims.
Earlier this year, the pope spoke out against what the U.N.
has called ethnic cleansing in Myanmar, and some are concerned about the impact if the pope repeats that message.
NPR's Sylvia Poggioli is traveling with the pope.
She joins us via Skype.
Hi, Sylvia.
Hi, David.
So why all the concerns here, I mean, if the pope is there to call for peace and to speak out for the Rohingya Muslims, who many see as victims of just terrible violence?
Well, the problem is here that the local Catholic church, local church officials - it's a very small community - they advised Pope Francis not to use the name.
It's a very - perceived as an inflammatory word, the Rohingya name, in - by the military, which is pretty much still in command of the situation and even by the great majority of Buddhists.
The Rohingya Muslims are widely seen here as illegal migrants, and they don't even have citizenship.
So there was fear.
The Catholic minority feared that if the pope were to use the word Rohingya that could unleash reprisals against Catholics.
So we're looking at not just the content of a speech, but, I mean, literally one word and whether he decides to use it or not and what message that would send in either direction.
Well, I think, you know, he will definitely - he will try to get his message across as forcefully as he can, avoiding what the powers that be have made taboo words.
It will be a semantic and diplomatic test for him.
He's known never to mince his words.
Now, this morning, we got maybe a little bit of a taste.

He met with - a taste of what he might say because he met with religious leaders of other faiths in Yangon, and Vatican officials said that what Francis stressed was, unity is always a product of diversity.

He told them everyone in every religion has their values, their riches, as well as their differences and traditions to share, and this can only happen, he added, if we live in peace, and peace is constructed in a chorus of differences.
So I think he will try to sort of, you know, balance the semantic tightrope in some way or another.
But Sylvia, I mean, this is a pope who is known for, as you said, not mincing words and also speaking up for the neediest in this world.
I mean, what is at stake for him and his reputation?
Well, it's a big problem because he, in fact - he's the champion of the downtrodden.
He's the moral authority, always speaking out on behalf of refugees and migrants all over the world.
But he also has to be very careful not to endanger the lives of this small Catholic minority here in the country.
And this is just one stop on a swing through Asia for the pope.
Is that right?
On Thursday, he travels to Bangladesh, a mostly Muslim country whose Catholics are even smaller proportion of the population than here in Myanmar.
But there, they're a pillar of the country's social welfare system with a network of schools and hospitals for everyone - Muslims and Christians.

There's been a bit of growing Islamic fundamentalism after years of interreligious coexistence, so the pope is going there also to encourage another small Catholic community in what he's fond of calling the periphery of the world.
NPR's Sylvia Poggioli traveling with the pope in Myanmar.
Sylvia, thanks.
Thank you, David.
This is WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Scott Simon.
The unemployment rate in the United States has fallen to 8.9 percent.
The U.S.
Labor Department released the new numbers yesterday.
It says that overall, the country gained 192,000 jobs last month.
Economists say that shows that job growth is finally gaining.
NPR's Chris Arnold reports.
